actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on March 11, 2025.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Ms. Kaptur moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.

Considered by unanimous consent. H. Con. Res. 17 — "Authorizing the use of Emancipation Hall in the Capitol Visitor Center for a ceremony as part of the commemoration of the days of remembrance of victims of the Holocaust."
Mr. Steil asked unanimous consent to discharge from committee and consider.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 406
actions-list.actionItem: 9 (Roll no. 65).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 993 — "To require the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop a plan to identify, integrate, and deploy new, innovative, disruptive, or other emerging or advanced technologies to enhance, or address capability gaps in, border security operations, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 410
actions-list.actionItem: 1 (Roll no. 64).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 901 — "To require the Under Secretary of the Science and Technology Directorate of the Department of Homeland Security to develop a Department-wide policy and process to safeguard research and development from unauthorized access to or disclosure of sensitive information in research and development acquisitions, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 402
actions-list.actionItem: 1 (Roll no. 63).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 495 — "To require annual reports on counter illicit cross-border tunnel operations, and for other purposes."
The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on motions to suspend the rules which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.

The House received a message from the Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Clerk notified the House that he had received the following message from the Secretary of the Senate on March 6, 2025, at 4:42 p.m.: That the Senate passed S. 524, S.J. Res. 3, S.J. Res. 28 and agreed to S. Res. 115.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 6:30 P.M. today.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the national emergency with respect to Iran that was declared on March 15, 1995, is to continue in effect beyond March 15, 2025
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 119-25).
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1374.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1374 — "To amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to make improvements to the Securing the Cities program, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the chair put the question on the motion to suspend the rules. Mr. Green (TN) objected to the vote on the grounds that a quorum was not present. Further proceedings on the motion were postponed. The point of no quorum was considered as withdrawn.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1692.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1692 — "To amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enable secure and trustworthy technology through other transaction contracting authority, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1166.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1166 — "To prohibit the Secretary of Homeland Security from procuring certain foreign-made batteries, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 993.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 993 — "To require the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop a plan to identify, integrate, and deploy new, innovative, disruptive, or other emerging or advanced technologies to enhance, or address capability gaps in, border security operations, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 901.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 901 — "To require the Under Secretary of the Science and Technology Directorate of the Department of Homeland Security to develop a Department-wide policy and process to safeguard research and development from unauthorized access to or disclosure of sensitive information in research and development acquisitions, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 708.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 708 — "To establish in the Department of Homeland Security a working group relating to countering terrorist, cybersecurity, border and port security, and transportation security threats posed to the United States by the Chinese Communist Party, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 862.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 862 — "To reduce commuting burdens on Transportation Security Administration employees, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the chair put the question on the motion to suspend the rules. Mr. Green (TN) objected to the vote on the grounds that a quorum was not present. Further proceedings on the motion were postponed. The point of no quorum was considered as withdrawn.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 706.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 706 — "To improve the biodetection functions of the Department of Homeland Security, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 495.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 495 — "To require annual reports on counter illicit cross-border tunnel operations, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Ms. Johnson of TX to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mariannette Miller-Meeks to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
